topics.title: Journalists serve audiences, not founders
topics.summary: Jason explains that writers/editors aren’t service providers and don’t inherently care about a founder’s company; they care about serving their readers/listeners. To earn coverage, you must frame your story as useful to that audience.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Jason Feifer and previews a tactical conversation on getting press: pitching, finding the right journalists, using freelancers, and defining success. Jason shares his media background and motivation to demystify press for founders.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Sidebar (peer groups/personal board of directors) and Maui Nui Venison (wild-harvested venison products).

topics.title: Pitch volume and inbox noise reality
topics.summary: Jason describes the huge daily volume of pitches (often irrelevant blasts) and how hard it is to stand out. They discuss the mix of PR vs founder outreach and how people end up on automated lists.

topics.title: What press can (and can’t) do
topics.summary: They cover the wide range of outcomes from press—sometimes major sales/download spikes, sometimes little direct impact. Jason emphasizes press is unpredictable and shouldn’t be the sole growth strategy.

topics.title: When to pursue press: define your purpose
topics.summary: Jason advises treating press like fundraising: only pursue it when you know what it’s for (launch awareness, fundraising credibility, etc.). He contrasts tactical goals with emotional motivations like “I deserve this.”

topics.title: Choose the right publication for your market
topics.summary: Using a DC hot dog truck example, Jason shows how national business press may be useless for local sales goals. He recommends targeting outlets whose audience can actually convert (e.g., local food publications).

topics.title: Three-step framework: prep, target, pitch
topics.summary: Jason lays out a simple process: prepare your story and goals, identify the right people/publications, then craft the pitch. He reiterates the key mindset shift: media serves audiences, not companies seeking coverage.

topics.title: Publication mission shapes what gets covered
topics.summary: Jason contrasts Fast Company’s (then) focus on the future of business with Entrepreneur’s focus on how entrepreneurs think through problems. He illustrates with the butter-dish founder: the product isn’t the story, the clever airport market-research tactic is.

topics.title: How to infer a publication’s mission
topics.summary: Jason explains there’s rarely a single “about” page that reveals editorial logic, especially for broad outlets like the New York Times. Instead, study sections, audiences, and patterns across stories to reverse-engineer what they value.

topics.title: Prep: pick goals and find your real story
topics.summary: Jason advises starting with a clear press goal, then identifying story angles that match the target outlet (different angles for Entrepreneur vs Cosmo). He warns against pushing generic announcements (e.g., executive hires) that don’t serve the outlet’s audience.

topics.title: Common press goals beyond awareness
topics.summary: They enumerate reasons to seek coverage: growth, entering new markets, brand positioning, executive authority-building, conference invites, partnerships, and investor credibility. The emphasis remains on being explicit about the intended outcome.

topics.title: PR agencies: when they help and red flags
topics.summary: Jason notes PR can save time but is often expensive and uneven in quality. He flags warning signs like press-release-first strategies, wire distribution vanity metrics, and guarantees; the best PR is relationship-driven and pushes back when a story isn’t a fit.

topics.title: Which publications to target and why
topics.summary: Jason resists a generic “top outlets” list because fit depends on whether you’re B2B, consumer, local, etc. He recommends starting by analyzing where competitors have been covered to identify relevant audiences and outlets.

topics.title: Press as validation: TechCrunch and beyond
topics.summary: Jason explains that the value of coverage is often downstream: credibility, “as seen in,” and leverage in outreach, not necessarily readership-driven conversions. He shares how Variety coverage didn’t drive immediate results but increased partner/advertiser attention.

topics.title: Who to pitch: avoid the editor-in-chief trap
topics.summary: Jason explains why pitching the most visible senior editor is often ineffective; EICs aren’t sourcing most stories day-to-day. Instead, identify the specific editors/writers covering your area by studying bylines and coverage patterns.

topics.title: Freelancers are hungry and often more receptive
topics.summary: Jason describes how freelancers must constantly pitch editors to get paid, making them more incentivized to find and develop stories. He contrasts this with staff editors’ inbox overload and notes journalists prefer discovering stories themselves, so pitches must be compelling.
